childhood_context.html:
Childhood: 1966-1978

You were born the year the Cultural Revolution swept China, the Black Panther Party was founded in Oakland, and Star Trek first aired on NBC. The Summer of Love was still a year away, but the '60s counterculture was already in full swing. Vietnam dominated the evening news every night. Your parents watched body counts scroll across the screen like sports scores.

Your early childhood was peak Cold War anxiety. Duck-and-cover drills were standard. The Cuban Missile Crisis was only four years in the rearview mirror when you arrived. Nuclear war felt possible in ways your kids will never understand. The space race was on—you were three when Armstrong walked on the moon. Half the country watched it live. You probably don't remember it, but you were there.

Watergate happened when you were six or seven. You watched Nixon resign on a TV set with wood paneling and rabbit ears. You didn't fully understand why, but you learned early that authority figures lie, that institutions fail, and that the people in charge don't always know what they're doing.

You grew up in a world without car seats, bike helmets, or participation trophies. You rode in station wagons with no seatbelts, drank from garden hoses, and stayed outside until the streetlights came on. Your parents smoked in the car with the windows up. The doctor smoked in his office. Everyone smoked everywhere.

Technology meant three TV channels, rotary phones, and AM radio. If you missed a show, you missed it. There was no recording, no streaming, no second chance. Delayed gratification wasn't a virtue—it was just how life worked.

generational_identity.html:
Your Generation: Gen X

You're Generation X, born between 1965 and 1980. The name came from a 1991 Douglas Coupland novel, but the identity was forged in the divorce courts and latchkey afternoons of the 1970s. There are roughly 65 million of you in the US—smaller than the Boomers before you and the Millennials after.

Your generation was defined by skepticism. You watched Watergate, stagflation, and the Iranian hostage crisis before you were a teenager. Your defining moments were the Challenger explosion, the fall of the Berlin Wall, and the AIDS epidemic. You learned early that institutions fail, heroes disappoint, and nothing is permanent.

Gen X raised itself. Both parents worked, or one parent was gone entirely. Divorce rates doubled during your childhood. You came home to empty houses, made your own dinners, and figured things out alone. This made you self-reliant, resourceful, and deeply suspicious of anyone claiming to have the answers.

You're sandwiched between two behemoth generations. Boomers get credit for changing the world. Millennials get blamed for ruining it. You're the middle child of American generations—overlooked, underestimated, and quietly running things while everyone argues about the other two.

Your generation invented slacker culture, grunge, and ironic detachment as a survival mechanism. You learned to expect nothing and demand less. This makes you resilient in ways that look like apathy to people who don't understand.

pop_culture.html:
Pop Culture Touchstones

You were born the year The Sound of Music dominated theaters and the Beach Boys released Pet Sounds. Batman premiered on TV—the campy Adam West version with the POW! and WHAM! sound effects. You arrived just as pop culture was about to get very weird.

Your childhood was Sesame Street and School House Rock—education disguised as entertainment. Saturday morning cartoons were sacred. You watched HR Pufnstuf, Scooby-Doo, and Land of the Lost before anyone questioned what the writers were smoking. Spoiler: probably everything.

Your teen years coincided with the birth of MTV. You remember when they actually played music videos. Michael Jackson's Thriller, Prince's Purple Rain, Madonna's everything—these weren't just songs, they were cultural events. You saw music become visual for the first time.

Movies in your formative years included Star Wars (you were eleven), Animal House, and Saturday Night Fever. By high school, it was The Breakfast Club, Ferris Bueller, and every John Hughes film that told you your adolescent angst was valid. These movies understood you in ways your parents didn't.

You grew up with album-oriented rock on FM radio, graduated to punk and new wave, and watched grunge emerge when you were in your mid-twenties. Music mattered in ways it doesn't anymore—mixtapes were love letters, concert tickets were rites of passage, and knowing the B-sides made you interesting.

Your pop culture was analog, physical, and communal. You owned records, not playlists. You rented movies, not streamed them. You waited in line for things. The anticipation was part of the experience.

technology.html:
Your Technology Timeline

You were born three years before the ARPANET, the internet's ancestor, sent its first message. Computers in 1966 filled entire rooms and were operated by men in lab coats. The technology you take for granted today was science fiction when you arrived.

Your childhood tech was analog: turntables, reel-to-reel tape, and televisions you had to adjust with pliers when the knob broke off. Long distance calls were expensive. Photography meant film, developing, and waiting a week to see if your pictures came out.

You were in your teens when home computers emerged. The Apple II came out when you were eleven. The IBM PC arrived at fifteen. You might have had a Commodore 64 or an Atari 2600. These weren't lifestyle devices—they were toys for nerds, conversation pieces that mostly gathered dust.

The World Wide Web launched when you were twenty-five. You were thirty when Amazon started selling books online. Thirty-one when Google launched. Thirty-five when the iPod arrived. You didn't grow up with this technology—you watched it invade your adult life, one gadget at a time.

This makes you the last generation to remember a fully analog world. You know how to read a physical map, write in cursive, and look things up in encyclopedias. You learned to use technology as an adult, which means you understand it as a tool rather than an environment. You can unplug in ways younger generations can't, because you remember what unplugged looked like.

You're tech-capable but not tech-native. You can operate the systems, but you weren't shaped by them. Your brain was wired before screens became ubiquitous. This is either a superpower or a liability, depending on the day.

historical_milestones.html:
Historical Milestones

You were born the same year Miranda rights were established—'you have the right to remain silent' entered the American vocabulary. The Supreme Court was reshaping civil liberties while Vietnam was reshaping everything else.

You were two when MLK and RFK were assassinated, weeks apart. Your parents remember where they were. You don't, but you grew up in the aftermath—the rage, the grief, the sense that the country was tearing itself apart. The 1968 Democratic Convention riots happened while you were still in diapers.

Vietnam ended when you were nine. You remember the images: helicopters lifting off embassy rooftops, desperate crowds clinging to landing gear. America lost a war, and nobody quite knew what to do with that information. Your parents had won World War II. Your generation watched them lose this one.

You were eleven when Elvis died, twelve when John Paul II became Pope, thirteen when the Iranian hostage crisis began. You were fifteen when Reagan was shot, when AIDS first appeared in medical journals, when MTV launched. Your teenage years were the early Reagan era—morning in America for some, midnight for others.

You were twenty-three when the Berlin Wall fell. The Cold War that defined your entire childhood just... ended. The Soviet Union collapsed. History was supposed to be over. Francis Fukuyama said so. He was wrong, but for a moment there, it felt like peace might be permanent.

You were thirty-five during 9/11. Old enough to have an established life, young enough for everything to shift underneath you. Your kids, if you had them, were young. You had to explain terrorism to children while processing your own shock. The forever wars that followed stretched through your forties and into your fifties.

You've watched the world remake itself multiple times. Cold War to post-Cold War. Analog to digital. Pre-internet to always-online. You've adapted to more change than any generation since the one that went from horses to cars to airplanes.

career.html:
Career & Professional Life

You entered the workforce in the mid-to-late 1980s, when the economy was recovering from recession and corporate culture was being redefined. Gordon Gekko told everyone greed was good. Hostile takeovers were glamorous. You started your career watching adults in suspenders destroy companies for profit.

Your generation pioneered the modern tech industry. You were the right age at the right time—old enough to understand computers, young enough to master them. The people who built Microsoft, Apple, Amazon, and Google are your age. You didn't just witness the digital revolution; you caused it.

You also pioneered burnout. The 80-hour work week was a badge of honor. 'Work hard, play hard' was your motto, and the 'play hard' part often meant cocaine. Your generation worked itself ragged building the economy that would later chew up your kids.

You survived multiple recessions: 1990-91, 2001, 2008. Each time, you watched layoffs, restructuring, and the evaporation of job security. You learned that loyalty to employers is a one-way street. You changed jobs more than your parents did, not by choice, but by necessity.

By now, you're in leadership positions—or you're supposed to be. You're the managers, the executives, the people making decisions. Boomers are finally retiring (slowly, reluctantly), and Millennials are pushing from below. You're running companies while getting blamed for everything both generations did.

Your generation normalized remote work before COVID made it mandatory. You built the tools, the infrastructure, the culture that allowed everyone to work from home. Then you spent two years in Zoom meetings wondering if this was really what you'd been building toward.

relationships.html:
Relationships & Communication

You're the generation that delayed marriage but still did it. The median age at first marriage jumped during your prime dating years—you got married later than your parents, earlier than your kids. You invented the extended adolescence that Millennials would later be mocked for.

Dating for your generation was pre-internet, mostly. You met people in person—at bars, through friends, at work. Classified ads existed, but they were for weirdos. Video dating was a punchline. You asked people out using landlines, with no preview of their text messaging style. You had to just... talk to them.

Your generation had the highest divorce rate in American history. You grew up watching your parents' marriages fail, and many of you replicated the pattern. But you also learned from it—second marriages had better odds, and you approached relationships with less delusion than the generations before.

You communicate across platforms now—text, email, phone, video—but you remember when communication meant either seeing someone in person or calling them. Long distance relationships meant long distance phone bills. Missing someone meant actually missing them, not just waiting for their message to load.

Your friendships are smaller but deeper than younger generations'. You don't have 500 friends; you have five close ones you've known for decades. You're suspicious of performative friendship, of social media connections that don't translate to actual support. You learned that real relationships require presence, not just proximity.

You're the sandwich generation now—caring for aging Boomer parents while supporting Millennial or Gen Z children who can't afford to launch. You're financially and emotionally squeezed from both directions. Nobody prepared you for this, because nobody prepared your parents for this either.

financial.html:
Financial Psychology

You came of age during the Reagan boom and the subsequent crashes. You've seen the market soar and implode, recovered and crashed again, multiple times. Your financial worldview is cautiously optimistic—things can get better, but they can also fall apart overnight.

You probably own a house, or at least bought one before they became unaffordable. Real estate appreciation has been kind to your generation. You bought when prices were sane and rode the wave up. This makes you wealthier on paper than your kids will ever be, through no particular virtue of your own.

Your retirement is a question mark. You have 401(k)s instead of pensions—the shift happened during your career. You're supposed to be self-directed investors, but half of you don't know what you're doing and the other half are terrified you'll outlive your savings. Social Security will exist when you retire, but who knows for how long.

You watched your parents retire comfortably with defined benefits and gold watches. You'll retire (if you retire) with whatever you managed to scrape together while putting kids through college and paying for your parents' assisted living. The math doesn't work, but you do it anyway.

Your generation holds significant wealth compared to Millennials and Gen Z, but less than Boomers. You're the middle child financially, too—not the beneficiaries of post-war prosperity, not the victims of post-2008 precarity. You caught the end of the good times and the beginning of the bad.

You're practical about money in ways that look boring to younger generations. You don't YOLO into meme stocks. You're suspicious of cryptocurrency. You've seen too many bubbles burst to believe this time is different. Your financial strategy is survival, not glory.

blind_spots.html:
Your Generational Blind Spots

Your biggest weakness is mistaking cynicism for wisdom. You've seen so much institutional failure that you've stopped expecting institutions to work. This protects you from disappointment but also from engagement. You've opted out of systems you could be fixing.

You're so proud of being self-reliant that you've forgotten how to ask for help. The latchkey years made you independent, but they also made you isolated. You suffer in silence because asking for support feels like weakness. Therapy was stigmatized when you were young, and some of that stigma stuck.

You dismiss younger generations the same way Boomers dismissed you. You call Millennials entitled. You roll your eyes at Gen Z's pronouns and social media habits. You've become the dismissive adults you resented as teenagers, and you don't always notice.

Your ironic detachment, which served you well in the '90s, now looks like apathy. You're hard to mobilize because you don't believe mobilization works. You've seen too many movements fizzle, too many promises break. But sometimes the cynical response is the wrong response, and you're not always good at knowing when.

You adapted so well to the digital world that you forget you didn't build it for yourselves. You use social media like immigrants—competently, but with an accent. You miss cultural references. You're out of touch with how younger people communicate, and you don't always realize it because the tools feel familiar even when the culture doesn't.

Your generation benefited from timing you didn't earn—affordable housing, available jobs, rising markets. You worked hard, but so did the generations after you. The difference is you worked hard during an economic expansion. Acknowledging luck alongside effort is difficult when your identity is built on self-reliance.

life_roadmap.html:
Life Phase Roadmap

Your 20s (1986-1996): You entered adulthood during the Reagan/Bush years and graduated into a recession. But the economy recovered, the Berlin Wall fell, and the '90s arrived with their ridiculous optimism. Your twenties were the last decade before the internet changed everything. You built careers, got married (maybe divorced), and watched the world transform from analog to digital. You were young enough to adapt, old enough to remember what came before.

Your 30s (1996-2006): The dot-com boom and bust happened on your watch. You rode the wave up, maybe crashed when it did. You had kids, bought houses, climbed corporate ladders. September 11th hit when you were thirty-five—old enough to have established lives, young enough for everything to shift. Your thirties were about building stability while the ground kept moving.

Your 40s (2006-2016): The 2008 financial crisis arrived when you were forty-two. You'd built enough equity to survive it, but you watched younger colleagues lose everything. Your kids were becoming teenagers. Your parents were becoming elderly. You were sandwiched—managing up and down simultaneously. This was your peak earning decade, but also your peak responsibility decade. Everything demanded your attention at once.

Your 50s (2016-2026): You're in this decade now. Trump, COVID, social upheaval—the hits keep coming. Your kids are adults (sort of). Your parents need more care (definitely). You're thinking about retirement but not sure you can afford it. You're senior enough at work to have power, tired enough to wonder why you wanted it. This is the decade where you either coast on what you've built or reinvent yourself entirely.

Your 60s (2026-2036): Retirement age, if retirement is still a thing you can do. Your health will dictate more than you'd like. The world will be run by people who don't remember a time before smartphones. You'll have grandchildren who can't fathom rotary phones or card catalogs. You'll tell stories about the '70s that sound like science fiction. You'll wonder if you did enough, built enough, mattered enough. Everyone does.

Your 70s and beyond (2036+): By now, you'll be the elder generation—the keepers of pre-digital memory, the ones who remember assassinations and moon landings and the fall of the Berlin Wall. Your grandchildren will interview you for school projects. You'll watch the world change in ways you can't predict and probably won't like. But you've adapted before. Gen X's defining trait is survival. You'll manage. You always have.

comparison.html:
Generational Comparison

You're part of a birth cohort of roughly 3.6 million people born in 1966. The entire Gen X generation is about 65 million people in the US—smaller than the Boomers (76 million) and Millennials (72 million). You're the forgotten middle child of American demographics.

Compared to Boomers (born 1946-1964), you're more skeptical and less entitled. Boomers inherited post-war prosperity and believed the world owed them something. You inherited Watergate and stagflation and learned to expect nothing. They got Woodstock. You got disco's funeral. They changed the world. You just tried to survive it.

Compared to Millennials (born 1981-1996), you're more self-reliant and less collaborative. They grew up with helicopter parents. You grew up with no parents home. They believe in institutions. You remember when institutions failed. They want work-life balance. You want to get the job done and go home. They're optimistic. You're realistic.

Compared to Gen Z (born 1997-2012), you're practically from another planet. They've never known a world without internet. You remember when long distance calls cost money. They communicate in memes. You still use complete sentences. They're digital natives. You're digital immigrants who learned the language but kept the accent.

Your life expectancy is around 78-80 years—similar to other recent generations but threatened by 'deaths of despair' that hit your cohort hard. Suicide, drugs, alcohol—Gen X has higher rates than Boomers did at the same age. The self-reliance that defined your generation also left you isolated when things went wrong.

Financially, you're doing better than Millennials but worse than Boomers. You caught the tail end of affordable housing and pensions. You built wealth when it was still possible. But you also caught multiple recessions, and the wealth gap between you and Boomers is significant. You're not as screwed as your kids. You're not as fortunate as your parents. You're in the middle, as always.

What sets your generation apart is adaptability. You've navigated more technological change than any generation in history. Typewriters to word processors to cloud documents. Letters to email to Slack. Record stores to Napster to Spotify. You didn't just witness these transitions—you managed them, often at work, explaining new systems to Boomers while learning them alongside Millennials. You're the translators between eras.

year_events: Black Panther Party founded in Oakland
Miranda rights established by Supreme Court
